I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) support Nepal’s inclusive and sustainable development with knowledge solutions and 
institutional capacity development. The TA will focus on knowledge solutions such as analytical 
and diagnostic studies to inform strategies, plans, and policies; institutional strengthening; and 
capacity development of government agencies especially at the subnational level. The TA will 
prioritize knowledge dissemination and will help implement the country knowledge plan of ADB’s 
country partnership strategy (CPS) for Nepal, 2020–2024.1 It will also enable ADB to respond to 
knowledge and institutional strengthening needs arising from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) 
pandemic and other emerging challenges.2  
 
2.  The TA is closely aligned with the government’s Fifteenth Plan (FY2020–FY2024)3 and 
ADB’s Strategy 2030.4 It is included in ADB’s country operations business plan, 2021–2023.5    
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Nepal’s  economic  growth  averaged  5.3%  during  FY2014–FY2019  and  7.3%  during 
FY2017–FY2019, higher than the average of 4.9% (FY2010-FY2019). In FY2020, the Central 
Bureau of Statistics estimates a fall in gross domestic product (GDP) growth to 2.3%, reflecting 
the  adverse  effects  of  the  COVID-19  pandemic.  Hotels  and  restaurants,  manufacturing, 
construction, transport, and trade have been particularly adversely affected. With large numbers 
of Nepali migrant workers returning home, remittances (25.4% of GDP in FY2019) have declined. 
The structural transformation that economies typically undergo as they develop—with a shift from 
agriculture to more productive manufacturing and services—has been gradual.6 Agriculture’s 
share in GDP declined from 49% in FY1990, but remains large at an estimated 27.6% of GDP in 
FY2020. Likewise, the share of manufacturing has declined from a recent peak of 9.0% of GDP 
in FY1998 to 5.1% in FY2020.7  Much of the growth is attributable to services. The economy is 
largely informal.8  
 
4.  Nepal has significant potential for higher production and exports of goods and services 
such as hydropower; tourism; high-value agriculture and agro-processing; and manufacturing of 
textiles,  garments,  and  footwear  (footnote  6).  These  sectors  have  the  potential  to  create 
substantially more productive jobs for the young and growing labor force and returning migrant 
workers. While an increase in public investment is necessary to realize the potential, it is equally 
important to improve the quality of such investments. That will entail developing knowledge 
solutions and stronger public institutions for better planning, management, and design and 
implementation of projects, programs, and policies; attracting domestic and foreign investment;

8  Among the employed in FY2018, 62.2% were in the informal sector. These informal workers accounted for 94% of

benefits (footnote 6).

2 
and ensuring healthy competition in the private sector so that the country’s scarce resources are 
allocated to more productive activities and used more efficiently.  
 
5.  The transition to a federal governance system mandated by the 2015 constitution and 
initiated since the 2017 elections raises the prospects of greater accountability and better delivery 
of public services. The constitution has assigned larger functional, semi-judicial, and fiscal 
management responsibilities to subnational governments (SNGs). The success of federalism 
depends largely on whether SNGs fulfill their constitutional mandates. Inadequate knowledge 
solutions and weak institutional capacity are major challenges in the transition to federalism, 
which  affect  the  government’s  ability  to  deliver  public  services  efficiently  and  implement 
development projects and programs. ADB must adapt its operations to the federal governance 
structure  and  clarify  the  roles  and  responsibilities  of  the  central,  provincial,  and  local 
governments.9 
 
6.  The government’s Fifteenth Plan (FY2020–FY2024) and its long-term strategy expect 
Nepal to reach a per capita income of $1,595 by FY2024, meet the Sustainable Development 
Goals by FY2030, and become a high-income country by 2047.10 The plan’s objectives include 
human capital development; universal, accessible, and modern infrastructure; higher production 
and  productivity  in  agriculture,  industry,  and  services;  a  healthy  and  balanced  ecosystem, 
including resilience to climate change and natural hazards; and good governance. The plan calls 
for the government to implement smoothly the federal system of governance and create an 
investment-friendly  environment  for  the  private  sector.  It  places  critical  importance  on  the 
accumulation of knowledge, skills, technology, and more generally, human and physical capital. 
With poverty and inequality likely to rise because of the COVID-19 pandemic, and given Nepal’s 
vulnerability to natural hazards, climate change, and environmental degradation, more inclusive 
and greener growth has become even more important. 
 
7.  Drawing on the government’s priorities, ADB’s CPS included three strategic objectives: (i) 
improved infrastructure for private sector-led growth; (ii) improved access to devolved services; 
and (iii) strengthened environmental sustainability and resilience to climate change and natural 
hazards (footnote 1). ADB’s country knowledge plan  focused on (i) policy advisory services with 
diagnostic studies and assessments of good practice models, including the feasibility of new 
technologies, appropriate for Nepal; (ii) planning and implementation mechanisms for inclusive 
and sustainable delivery of quality infrastructure and social services, especially at the subnational 
levels; and (iii) capacity development of relevant stakeholders (Appendix 2 of footnote 1). The 
COVID-19 pandemic has underscored the importance of health services; social protection; food 
security;  employment  generation  including  in  micro,  small,  and  medium-sized  enterprises; 
appropriate labor force skills to respond to changing markets; essential infrastructure; efficient 
supply chain management; and promotion of gender equality and social inclusion (GESI). With 
restrictions on in-person interactions, the use of digital technology has assumed greater urgency.   
 
8.  One of the key lessons from ADB’s experience in Nepal is the need to incorporate 
sustainability mechanisms in ADB operations, including disaster-resilient project designs, well-
coordinated  policy  and regulatory reforms,  institutional capacity  development,  and  effective 
communication  and  coordination  during  project  design  and  implementation  (footnote  9). 
Recommendations  include  an  increased  focus  on  institutional  strengthening,  capacity 
development, and governance reform, including support to key intergovernmental subsystems to 
facilitate the transition to the federal system. ADB needs to buttress its support for knowledge, in 
 
9  ADB. 2018. Country Partnership Final Review: Nepal, 2013–mid-2018. Manila. 
10  The long-term strategy targets per capita GDP of $12,100 by 2047.

3 
addition to finance, by communicating more effectively what it does and what it can do to help 
achieve the country’s development objectives.11 At the corporate level, ADB should substantially 
enhance the scope of knowledge contribution to add to development finance in the future, thereby 
deepening ADB’s continuous transformation.12 
 
9.  ADB’s  TA  in  strengthening  the  institutional  capacity  of  government  and  providing 
knowledge solutions is timely and important given the capacity and knowledge gaps in (a) 
implementing policy and institutional reforms, (b) designing high-impact projects and programs, 
(c) planning and resource allocation, (d) making quality investments, (e) delivering public services 
efficiently under the federal system of governance, and (f) addressing medium-term challenges 
likely to emerge from the COVID-19 pandemic. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: knowledge, skills, technology, and human and 
physical capital enhanced (footnote 3). The TA will have the following outcome: Design and 
implementation of development policies, strategies, programs, and projects improved. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  Output 1: Knowledge solutions produced and events organized for inclusive and 
sustainable development. The TA will support the generation and dissemination of knowledge 
products covering various sectors and themes, as well as knowledge events. The TA will support 
analytical, diagnostic, and feasibility studies, including with surveys, based on their alignment with 
the ongoing or planned government and/or ADB initiatives.13 Policy reform strategies, plans, and 
policy briefs will be prepared based on the findings of these studies. Lessons from past operations 
will be drawn through case studies and used in the design of projects and for policy and 
institutional  reforms.  GESI  aspects  will  be  considered  in  the  knowledge  products  when 
appropriate. Knowledge sharing events will be organized to share findings from these studies and 
plans. Interactive forums and seminars on other development and policy issues relevant to Nepal 
will also be organized.  
 
12.  Output 2: Policies, strategies, and plans to improve institutional capacity of public 
institutions  prepared.  The  TA  will  support  capacity  development  of  public  institutions, 
particularly at the SNG level. This will include support for (i) preparing acts, regulations, and 
policies that incorporate gender and climate change-related features when feasible; (ii) setting up 
institutional structures;14 reporting mechanisms; and operational systems, including the use of 
digital technology (para. 13); and (iii) developing strategies and plans to improve local economic 
development and employment generation by focusing on areas such as domestic resource 
mobilization;  micro,  small,  and  medium-sized  enterprise  development;  and  public–private 
partnerships.  
 
11 ADB. 2019. Nepal: Validation of the Country Partnership Strategy Final Review, 2013–mid-2018. Manila. 
12 ADB. 2020. Knowledge Solutions for Development: An Evaluation of ADB’s Readiness for Strategy 2030. Manila. 
13 The studies could include diagnostic studies of potential tourist destinations; possibilities for electrification of Nepal 
to make it fossil-fuel free; digital platforms to connect different stakeholders in the agriculture value chain; alternative 
modalities such as public–private–community partnerships in solid waste management and agriculture extension; 
and analytical studies on developing and effectively operating special economic zones. 
14 For example, determining the number and type of functional divisions/sections and human resources based on the 
institutional mandate, as determined by government laws or regulations.

4 
 
13.  The TA will support at least one SNG institution’s efforts to install digital technologies, 
such  as  a  facility  for  video  conferencing,  and  to  automate  its  administrative  and  financial 
management system to help it function effectively and deliver public services even during crises 
such as the COVID-19 pandemic.15 Where necessary, the TA will also support institutional 
assessments and preparation of institutional strengthening plans for select government agencies 
in relation to their specific development operations or their mandates. This support could include 
assessing a provincial government’s capacity for disaster risk management or crisis management 
for events such as COVID-19, and developing a plan to manage such risks. Support will also be 
provided to prepare communication strategies that will improve coordination among government 
agencies at different tiers.  
 
14.  Output  3:  Skills,  capacity,  and  knowledge  of  government  officials  and  other 
stakeholders enhanced.16 The TA will support capacity development through selected training 
programs.  While ADB is delivering training related mainly to project implementation through the 
Capacity Development Resource Center at the Nepal Administrative Staff College,17 this TA will 
provide training in other functional areas at all tiers of government. Training programs in specific 
areas and for particular skills will be determined by the institutional strengthening plans of the 
government agencies (para. 13), and as requested by the government. This will include tailor-
made executive programs for senior government officials to enhance leadership and management 
skills.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.5 million, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff and other in-kind 
contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The International Economic Cooperation Coordination Division (IECCD) of the Ministry of 
Finance will be the executing agency of the TA. The resident mission will administer the TA in 
close coordination with government agencies, development partners, and other ADB-funded 
programs, projects, and TA to ensure complementarity and avoid duplication.  
 
17.  The  implementation  period  will  be  5  years  from  the  date  of  TA  approval.  The 
implementation of the TA will be guided by a TA advisory committee, which will be formed under 
the leadership of the resident mission country director (as knowledge custodian). Heads of 
resident mission programs and portfolio units, the knowledge focal person, and external relations 
officer will be the committee members. The resident mission knowledge focal person (currently 
the senior programs officer) will be responsible for the day-to-day management of the TA.  
 
18.  Resident mission staff will support government counterparts in preparing and submitting 
proposals for TA support. The list of proposals received by ADB will be shared with the IECCD 
for  feedback.  The  proposals  will  be  discussed  at  TA  advisory  committee  meetings.  Such 
 
15  Training and an operational manual will be provided. This could be replicated in other local governments. 
16  Other stakeholders could include communities and civil society organizations, especially at the subnational levels. 
17  The Capacity Development Resource Center is funded by ADB. TA 9800-NEP: Portfolio Management and Capacity 
Development for Enhanced Portfolio Performance. Manila.

5 
proposals will be evaluated for (i) alignment with the ongoing or planned government and/or ADB 
initiatives; (ii) expected results; (iii) clear knowledge and/or capacity needs that have not been 
met by the government’s own initiatives, or by the support of other development partners, or 
ADB’s  other  ongoing  and  planned  projects  and  TA;  and  (iv)  ownership  and  capacity  of 
government agencies to achieve the results in a timely manner. The proposals will be approved 
upon the concurrence of the IECCD. The resident mission staff submitting the proposal will serve 
as the project officer for the proposed work and will be responsible for its deliverables, will report 
to the committee, and will prepare the final report.18

20.  Consulting services. ADB will engage (international and national) consultants following

required number of inputs in person-months will depend on the nature of the work and will be 
included in the proposals that are submitted to the TA advisory committee for approval. Where 
feasible, ADB will use output-based, lump-sum contracts with a provision for fixed out-of-pocket 
expenditures. For knowledge events, proposals could include an honorarium for the experts 
invited  as  speakers  or  resource  people.  ADB  will  also  engage  a  knowledge  management 
coordinator  and  a  part-time  national  consultant  to  help  administer  the  TA  during  the  TA 
implementation period. The terms of reference for the consultants are in the linked document. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Nepal for Knowledge Solutions and Institutional Strengthening for Sustainable 
Development, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
